page.title: 16Fordingbridge - 1905.
page.content: An 87 year old, who has lived throughout his life in this locality, talked about the life and work of the people when he first attended school. The roads, being made of flint from the Downs, were regularly watered by the horse-drawn water cart to keep the dust down.{Travel}was by horse-drawn vehicles. There were no cars until about 1905 (Mr.Neave's) and about three years later there were only two more in the area (the local doctors'). On market day the farmers would travel to Salisbury by train. Very few people had bicycles and about half of these were penny-farthings. All the men were{employed locally.}They either worked on the farm, in the brickyards, at Neaves Baby Food Factory (100 employees), at the Vineries (30 employees), were tradesmen or worked in the local service industries.
